aren't familiar DRS stands for distributed resource scheduling it's a capability built into vSphere and the basic idea is if you
have a VCR cluster a set of ESX hosts hosts what DRS will do is look at all
the VMS running across those ESX hosts and move them around so that there are most optimally place for best
performance right so you don't have one host is so overloaded well although all the other ones are doing nothing now one
of the limitations of DRS historically has been that if the cluster itself was just overloaded there's just too many
workloads there there's nothing DRS can do about it right because DRS has no way of you know
calling an API to add more hosts you can't do that on premises so that necessarily limitation of DRS per se is
just a limitation of the whole model but the cool thing about the cloud is that
we can do this so AWS has done something pretty phenomenal in my opinion and that is somehow automated reality right you
can automate software I haven't seen it galatea automated that often so now we can call an API and all of a sudden a
new physical host appears connected to the network where this physical host comes from or how it happens I don't know but somehow it all happens
